Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Grayndler) (5.30 p.m.)Mr Speaker, you would recall that today you acknowledged tl)e presence in the gallery of some 240 student leaders attending a conference entitled 'National Student Leadership Forum on Faith and Values'. This afternoon I went and had a look to see exactly what that National Student Leadership Forum on Faith and Values was all about. It makes interesting reading because it has an itinerary which has a number of seminar topics over the next few days. It has been organised primarily by the federal member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) and other people across the parties but particularly dominated by members of the Lyons Forum. The names of Abbott, Abetz, Andrews, Bradford, Cadman, Cameron, Chapman, Miles, Slipper and Tambling roll off the tongue. And what is it that the Lyons Forum sees as the leadership which should be put in tomorrow's leaders of Australia? What is it - that they are training tj1em in? Tonight there is a dinner at this parliament and tonight in this parliament-this fine democratic institution-the person who will be lecturing Australia's future leaders on faith and values and, one would assume, on democratic faith and values, is none other than,the Hon. Major General Sitiveni Rabuka. I just think it is a bit hypocritical for the Lyons Forum, who lecture us about moralsÂ· and lecture us about values, to bring someone to this democratic parliament to lecture' Australia's future young leaders and to present him as a role model because, Mr Speaker, I am sure that you would agree that role models for Australian democracy do not come in the form of people who enter parliaments with guns and gas masks. I well recall a few years those horrific scenes in the Fijian parliament where, after losing a democratic election, General Rabuka staged and led a military coup in 1987. As a result of that coup, there are a number of constituents in my electorate who are refugees of that military takeover of that country, who were forced to flee that country due to the oppression which took place, particularly against the Fiji Labour Party, after that coup in 1987. When you look at the speaker profile that, one would assume, the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) has put out, it says: 'Prime Minister Rabuka has been an integral part of the most fundamental and political constitutional reform Fiji has ever experienced.' That is true; you lose an election, so you come into parliament with a gun and I just think

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I think the honourable member needs to be careful. I know he is treading a fine line, but I think you need to be careful in what you are saying.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Thank you, Mr Speaker, but I am sure you would agree that the role models we present for young Australians are important. I just think that in terms of the role models that should be presented, particularly in a country which embodies democratic values as we do, it is important who we pick. I wonder if, when the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) presents his seminar topic, which is called 'Leadership motivation: case studies in overcoming disappointment', he looks at General Rabuka. General Rabuka overcame disappointment of losing an election. He found a very unique way of overcoming that disappointment. I really think it is inappropriate. I came into this parliament on 2 March 1996 after 13 years of Labor government and there was a majority across the other side. That is democracy. It is very important that we provide appropriate role models for young Australians and it is particularly important that in this parliament we have a consistent view of democratic values and oppose breaches of them, whether they be of the extreme left or of the extreme right. It is particularly important. I expressed my concern because I am sure that the students who have come to this conference have come with goodwill. I certainly wish them all the best and hope that they enjoy the experience that - hey have here. I think that it is a very good thing to happen, to have students coming here and learning from our processes. But I certainly hope that they learn and go away having a great commitment to democracy and the values which Australia holds dear. (Time expired) Aged Care

Speaker: Ms JEANES
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Kingston) (5.34 p.m.)Today the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) announcedÂ· a package that will provide further assistance to some of Australia's most needy people and to those who assist them. The package announced by the Prime Minister will provide an extra $270 million over four years to assist frail and elderly Australians, people with disabilities and their carers. The package will provide an extra $92 million over four years for community aged care packages to assist around 3,900 more frail and elderly Australians with high levels of dependency to stay in their homes-something we as members are so often told by them that they want. The package will also provide an extra $15 million for continence assistance; an extra $30 million for 15 more carer respite centres; an extra $10 million for additional respite care places for people with dementia; an extra $15 million for accommodation services for the adult children with profound disabilities of elderly carers; an extra $91 million for expanded eligibility for the domiciliary nursing care benefit; and an extra $13.7 million for aged care assessment. The frail and elderly, those with disabilities and the people who care for them really are some of our most outstanding people. It is often easy to become disheartened by the people you come across in this job, who think that the world owes them something, who hate it when someone gets something that they do not and therefore deem it to be wrong. They often fail to see the needs of others and to accept that the best person who can help them is indeed themselves. But the carers and the people they are for are so often the people who restore one's faith in human nature. The carers work tirelessly and selflessly to care for those that they love, because they have to. One of the aspects of the Prime Minister's announcement today that particularly delights me is the extra money for community aged care packages. In my electorate, a number of organisations receive money from the government to manage these packages for frail and elderly people, to assist them to stay in their homes. One such organisation is the Aged Care and Housing Group Inc., which arranged for me to visit families receiving help from the packages. On one visit Joylene Thomas took me to meet Dorothy and Dennis of Morphett Vale, who have been married for 58 years. Their story is a great story of a lifetime of commitment and love. Dorothy is very frail and she has dementia, but after 58 years of living together Dennis could not bear to have her leave him, so the Aged Care and Housing Group Inc. and a number of other organisations provide assistance to help Dennis manage Dorothy's needs. The services, in fact, feel that Dennis and Dorothy have taught them a lot in terms of how to improve their service delivery and how to deal with clients who, better than anyone else, know just what they need. One of the organisations which also provides help to Dennis and Dorothy, and to many other families in Adelaide's southern suburbs, is the City of Onkaparinga's respite service for frail and elderly people er people with moderate to severe disabilities, run by community development support officer, Pauline Smith. Pauline and her staff are tireless workers and advocates for the people they assist and they have deeply impressed upon me the need for the government to invest further in assisting their lies, as we have done today. There are two people in particular that I would like to pay tribute to at this point, Jean Leigh-Tamblyn and Jocelyn Gibson. Not only do they have their hands full with their own children who have disabilities; they provide great support to each other and to other parents in the southern suburbs of Adelaide through their group, Parents of the Disabled or PODS. Jean and Jocelyn will never let me forget their situations and today's announcement is a great tribute to people like them who not only deal with their own situations but who help others deal with theirs. People with disabilities and those - ho care for them are some of the most fatigued and forgotten people in Australia. It is worth noting why it is difficult for them to gain acknowledgment of their needs. The elderly, the frail and the disabled are often disenfranchised because of their difficulties in communicating their needs, and their carers are disenfranchised because they have little time or energy to do anything else but provide care. There are many programs that provide assistance across the health and family services and social security portfolios and the government has built further on its commitments to frail and elderly Australians, Australjob ians with disabilities and their carers today. The government has had a difficult task over the past two years in dealing with the budget deficit. The aim of the government's economic management has been to reduce its deficit and thus the amount of taxpayers' money going to pay interest bills, to reduce interest rates and inflation to provide an attractive destination for investment and thus to provide employment. To do this it has had to reduce its own spending. In spite of this aim, the government has recognised the need to boost spending on services for the most needy people-the frail and elderly, the and young- disabled and their carers. Today's announcement will go a long way to fill the gaps in services and entitlements for some of Australia's most vulnerable and tired Australians. I am pleased to be a part of a government that recognises their needs and I am most proud of the people in my area who fami- have helped me understand these needs .. Industrial Awards

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Barton) (5.38 p.m.)I wonder if members of the government are proud of the government's treatment of ordinary wage and salary earners. This government is to be condemned for its complete incompetence in the industrial relations field. I note that the government is opposing any pay rise in proceedings currently before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission for any wage in excess of $451.20 a week. That is poverty level wages-$23,400 per year. Even for those people they are only agreeing to a two per cent increase when executive salaries over the past 12 months have risen by about six per cent. That shows the priorities of the government in terms of being against the interests of ordinary wage and salary earners. Even more insidious is what is happening on 1 July. What will happen on 1 July is the gutting of industrial awards back to 20 core conditions. We have already seeri an example in respect of one hospitality award where the Australian Industrial Relations Commission applied the government's legislation. I should note from the government's own explanatory memorandum what this is going to mean for security. While the act allows redundancy pay to be included in an award, the explanatory memorandum prepared by the minister explicitly states that section 89A of the act will not operate to allow the inclusion in awards of provisions which will affect the capacity of an employer to determine the number or identity of a person who may be made redundant. Equally, the provisions will not allow the inclusion in awards of procedures that must be followed before notice of termination is given. Let us look at how that has been applied in a specific incidence-and that is in respect of the hospitality award. The commission gutted from that award the following provisions. They have been taken out of the award and will no longer be available to workers in that industry. From 1 July these provisions will not be available to any worker under an industrial award. Those provisions which have been removed are: the employer no longer has an obligation to notify and consult about the introduction of change-gone. There is no longer a requirement for discussions to take place prior to redundancies-gone. There are no longer provisions requiring the employer to notify the Commonwealth Employment Service in respect of impending redundancies-gone. The employee is no longer protected from receiving notice of termination of his or her employment while they are on authorised" leave-so the employee can get the bullet while they are at home sick. No longer is the employer required to provide employees with a statement of employment on terminationgone. These provisions have been around since 1984. On 1 July for all" Australian workers these provisions have gone out of their awards-gone, dead, kaput. The provision that termination of employment shall not be harsh, unjust or unreasonable has gone. Overnight that has been taken out of the award. There are a number of other significant provisions that have been taken from awards, for instance, provisions for the employer to provide items of clothing, tools, equipment, laundering and accommodationgone; provisions relating to sexual harassment-gone; provisions regarding the provision of a first aid kit-gone. Mrs Elizabeth Grace-You negotiate them in an agreement.

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The honourable member on the other side said that they are all up for negotiation. That is all right if have some industrial strength or might behind you. Those workers who are in unionised establishments might be okay. The member might have a look at the fact that the government has taken out section 170QK from the act which enabled the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to make an order that the parties bargain in good faith. So no longer do we have a situation where the outcomes are determined on the basis of reasoned argument. What is going to happen under this government is institutionalised anarchy. The victor out of this institutionalised anarchy is going to be the one with the economic might or the one with the industrial might. Reason and logic will not prevail and those workers who are without industrial strength are going to be the ones who suffer. Paradoxically, this government has hit non-unionised workers the hardest because from 1 July their fundamental employment security provisions are gone. (Time expired) Grafton Meatworks

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I wish to raise an issue this evening about an abattoir in my electorate where there are some very serious concerns for the employees and creditors in the city of Grafton. In about September last year the abattoir went into an administrator's hands appointed by the company itself-a company called R.J. Gilbertson. The administrator had to settle the affairs of the company, which found that it could not continue to trade. Apparently there were debts to the ANZ Bank of some $3.2 million, and there were debts to the employees themselves for entitlements, and some of those entitlements go back 30 years. People have had entitlements owing to them for 30 years, some $3 million. Creditors around the town-which included many small businesses, some cattle producers, who, find it very difficult at the present time, let alone when they lose their money, and agents who dealt with the cattle producersare owed some $3 million. This caused great consternation in the community, particularly for people who were you unaware that there were troubles with the abattoir. They had managed their affairs in such a way that they believed their employment would continue. There was some consternation, of course, when the company said that, even though there was a valuation on the abattoir of some $8 million, which would have gone a long way towards paying the creditors, it seemed that a sale of the abattoir would not realise much more than $3 million, which would only payout the secured creditor, the ANZ Bank. I became involved with this matter because of the concern of the company's workers and its creditors. I also had some support from Senator Bill O'Chee, a National Party senator who has had experience in this area of company law. We found that some very interesting things had taken place. For instance, on 27 June 1997, two cheques were drawn on the company and paid to other companies in the ownership of these people. Cheques which came to something like $5.845 million had been transferred. This, in itself, seemed quite strange. I immediately contacted the Australian Securities Commission to see whether they would. have a close look at the operations of this company and the performance of the directors. I also got in contact with the administrahave tqr to ask some questions about these payments. The administrator, Mr S.L. Horne,. from a firm of chartered accountants in Melbourne, said they had not realised these payments until I drew them to their attention. They did speak to me some weeks later and said that the directors acknowledged the fact that there were some concerns and there would be some more guarantees forthcoming from the directors of the company. In the last two days I have received a couple more letters from the accounting firm. One that came yesterday causes me some concern. What it says, if you read it carefully, is that the guarantee that is being given may be of little value, if at all, to the creditors. The letter from Clarke and Company referred to the company's assets. They say clearly that they may not yield any funds available for distribution for some 21h years and that they are fully encumbered. Moreover, it would appear to have escaped Clarke and Company's attention that, in the interim, these companies may well incur other liabilities over which the creditors of the two companies currently under administration will have no priority. The only way in which existing unsecured creditors of the meat works could possibly be protected from this is if a charge or charges are created in their favour. This has not been offered. The letter from Clarke and Company indicates their intention to only call a meeting of creditors in the event that Messrs Ferrier Hodgson fail to confirm the directors' representations, whatever that may mean. I do believe this matter, which is within the discretion of Clarke and Company, to be very serious. Creditors have a right to have all the facts. They have a right to have a meeting. Messrs Clarke and Company have no right to execute a legal document that precludes the creditors from having the opportunity to decide the future of these companies. I have been in touch with the Australian Securities Commission and they share the worries I have about some of the actions of the directors of this company. They believe that the creditors should be given a chance to another meeting and they believe that the creditors should retain their own advisers to protect them. (Time expired) Economic Rationalism

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: One of the most insidious 'isms' that has ever been created must be economic rationalism, especially as it has been practised during the 1990s. Throughout both the private sector and the public sector there have been decisions under the guise of economic rationalism that have dehumanised society at the community level. Take, for example, the wholesale closure of bank branches throughout Australia. The effect of this has been to see, in the last 12 months, a shedding of 10,000 full-time jobs and further promised cuts of 10 per cent. This comes after the big four had already cut 6,300 positions in 1997. Figures show that between 1990 and 1996 employment by the big four banks had reduced by 26 per cent. Also, there has been the closure of something like 20 per cent of branches in similar periods. In my own electorate, we see that the ANZ Bank is to close a branch in the suburb of South Morang on 15 May-a branch that ANZ only opened in 1991. South Morang is a developing suburb in the electorate. Although the population is only 2,500 at the moment, it is predicted to be, by 2010, a thriving suburb of 23,900. Some of the other suburbs in the western side of the electorate of Scullin fare little better. In the Mill Park suburb, with a population of 26,500 and still growing, only two of the big four are present. In a suburb like Thomastown, with a population of 22,200, the ANZ is to merge its branch in High Street, Thomastown, with its Lalor branch. The National Bank closed its Thomastown branch and has told people living in the residential areas of Thomastown that they should bank at its business centre in the industrialised areas of that suburb. One has to ask what it is that the banks are setting out to achieve. At a time when there are record profits, we see this wholesale red-tion of the number of employees that the banks have. We see this in the guise that this is a service industry. Anybody who visits local branches knows that there are long queues, that when people approachand finally get to do their business,' the. employees of banks are forced to badger customers into considering new products, when all they want to do is simply go into the bank, do their business and get out. We see this phenomena throughout Australia-not only in the urban fringes like the electorate of Scullin, but also in rural areas Australia. Of course, this gets a lot of coverage in this place and a lot of government members shed crocodile tears about bank closures. But we must also consider that the basis of these decisions, as I said earlier,' is the economic rationalism theo'ry of downsizing and greater efficiency. What have we seen in the public sector under the Howard government? Downsizing and closures. If we look at rural Australia, we see the closure of tax offices. If we look at what has occurred throughout Australia, we see the closure of Medicare offices-of course, predominantly in Labor electorates, but that is another argument. In the city of Whittlesea there has never been a Medicare office. The nearest Medicare office is in the suburb of Reservoir in the seat of Batman, and that, of course, closed last month. Now, people who want to do business direct, face to facepeople such as the elderly and migrants prefer to do that-have to go an extra five to 10 kilometres to centres like Northland in Preston or to Greensborough. Under this government we have seen the closure of CES offices. Some continue under the label 'Employment National', but in my electorate the CES office in Epping is to be closed on 1 May. It did not get a tender in this brave new world of labour market programs, so another public service will be denied the people of Scullin. If we look at post offices, the post offices at both Thomastbwn and Bundoora are presently under investigation because it is claimed that their activity is not enough to make them profitable. We see this continuing phenomena where people. feel remote from their communities because the things that they thought were part of the community-banks, post offices, and so on-are being denied them. Whereas the postmaster and the local branch manager were part of the local community, now everything is so remote. This leads to dehumanisation of communities where people feel less secure, they feel remote from the processes. They feel uncomfortable that all this is going on and they are helpless to do anything about it. Hopefully at some stage we will see the of counter to economic rationalism, we will see that people want to put back that human factor, we will see that people are not satisfied with just dealing with machines. People want to be counted as people; they want to be provided with direct face-to-face services. These are the things that both the public and the private sector need. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mrs DRAPER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Thank you, Mr Speaker, for the birthday wishes. I rise tonight to speak on the $270 million Staying at Home: Care and Support for Older Australians package which was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) today. Once again, the government has shown its commitment to and support of older Australians and their right to age with independence, choice and dignity. The government's aim is to ensure that older Australians have a real choice in determining whether they stay at home or choose to enter residential care. This new package has been welcomed across the board and I am sure that the Australian community will be delighted. I am particularly delighted on behalf of my constituents in Makin. The government's new package will demonstrate its underlying commitment to respect the rights of elderly Australians and to provide the support they need where they want it and when they want it. The Staying at Home: Care and Support for Older Australians package includes $92 million, to more than double the number of people who receive support through community aged care packages. The number of community aged care packages will be expanded by 3,900 over the next four years. Together with the growth in existing programs, this will more than double the number of people assisted to 22,000. The package will also cater for people with more complex care needs, including nursing care: $131 million has been allocated to secure increased eligibility for ance, the expansion of the carer respite centres and additional respite care places for people with dementia; the successful carer respite centres initiative will be expanded from 58 to 73; funding for aged care assessment will be indexed to growth in the older population to enable people to access care appropriate to their needs; and $15 million has been allocated for the development of alternative accommodation options for ageing carers of an adult with a disability. About 8,000 people aged 65 years or more currently care for adult children with a profound disability. Many of them have been carers for 40 years or more. We will spend an extra $15 million over four years on accommodation services for this group through the Commonwealth-state disability agreement. Fifteen million dollars will be spent to improve information and training about continence management, a major factor leading to entry to residential care. Continence assistance will make it easier for older people to manage at home and avoid unwanted admission to residential care. The Prime Minister's announcement has shown that the government is listening. I have spent a lot of my time here in Canberra discussing these issues with the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) on behalf of my constituents. I am delighted that the government has undergone extensive consultation processes with carers and community groups to ensure support for people who generously provide an important service to the community as carers for the elderly or the disabled. The new package will ensure that the aged care sector is strong and viable. This includes ensuring that staying at home and receiving community care is a real option for those older Australians who choose to do so. Our government is committed to fostering a sense of pride in the achievement of older Australians and recognising their continuing contribution to the community. As Australia's population ages, we need to take up the challenge to make the most of this invaluable a carers allowresource--our aged. Parliamentary Standards Hindmarsh Island Bridge

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I am concerned about the practice that has crept into the House of selective quoting of public documents and public records. That occurred today in question time when the minister selectively quoted a selective quote that was used 'on 29 May 1997 in terms of something that I said in relation to the stolen generationsThe other thing that concerns me is that a practice might come into this House whereby public documents that have been circulated by ministers are marked 'Confidential' with the intent to selectively quote and use the marking of 'Confidential' on a public document, perhaps circulated by the Attorney-General, in an attempt not to have that document tabled so that it is not taken in full context. Mr Speaker, I would implore you to look at this practice so that we do not have a repeat of today's situation. If this House is to be held in standing, there are certain rules. is happening here is that we are all being brought into disrepute. Also, I was ashamed when I was sitting in the High Court during the challenge to the Hindmarsh Island bridge - case to hear the Commonwealth government's legal representatives say to the court and submit to the court that the constitution was an inherently racist document and that the 1967 referendum meant that the whole of the constitution now has the value system of 1901. I was disturbed. I am pleased that the High Court did not buy that argument and that two judges of the High Court yesterday ruled that the races power could not be used to the detriment of Aboriginal people. There were two judges who said that it could be used to the positive or the negative but it was qualified and that it might be an abuse of the power and reserved the definition of what abuse of power was, and there were two judges did not comment. Fortunately, the government submission was - not picked up by any of the judges of the High Court. But I do implore you, Mr Speaker, to look at what happened in question time today and probably come back to the House to improve the standards so it cannot be repeated.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The member for Grayndler mentions General Rabuka. It is true that General Rabuka, now Prime Minister Rabuka of Fiji, will be the guest of honour and principal speaker at a dinner tonight. Like member for Grayndler, and I dare say all members of this House, I was appalled by the coup that took place in Fiji in 1987. Last night in fact a number of members of this House-Liberal, Labor and Independent-had a dinner with General Rabuka where these matters were discussed. It turns out that he was appalled by what happened in 1987. He judged that it was necessary, given the exigencies of the situation in Fiji at the time. Mr Albanese_It's like the holocaust?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: My judgment is that he was wrong. My judgment is that nothing short of the direst civil strife can ever justify sort of thing that was done. I judge General Rabuka to have been wrong. I judge what he did to be appalling. I think that what General Rabuka has been trying to do since that time is to bind up the wounds of the nation. I am pleased to see that under his sponsorship a non-racial constitution is about to be implemented again in Fiji. The simple truth is that there are many speakers who will be gracing the National Student Leadership Forum on Faith and Values. The purpose of the forum is 'To inspire young people to a life of leadership based on a commitment to serve others'. That is why I am delighted that people like the member for Banks and the member for Werriwa will be amongst the many people who will speak to the forum and who will share their insights with the youngsters who are attending it. The leaders who are talking to the forum include John Howard. No doubt the member for Grayndler will say, 'Well, there you go; John Howard addressing this forum,' but I have just come from part of that forum and who was speaking? None other than Kim Beazley himself. It gives me no pleasure to come into this House and take issue with the member for Grayndler on something which really should be a unifying feature of this parliament. I think it is a great thing that so many members of this parliament are prepared to come together and co-sponsor this forum. (Extension of time granted) The member for the Grayndler has perhaps allowed his exuberance to get the better of him. I think that the member for Grayndler's understandable desire to attack his political enemies has in this case caused him to take several steps too far. I say this not in any desire to embarrass the member for Grayndler but I really think he would be doing himself a favour-he would be honouring his Labor colleagues who are participating in this forum and his fellow members of parliament who are participating in this forum, and he would be paying due respect to the Prime Minister and to the Leader of the Opposition who are participating in this forum-if he were to offer some the kind of explanation and perhaps even some small apology for what he said.

ANZA C Ships Project (Question No. 2771) Mr Allan Morris asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 March 1998: (1) Has his attention been drawn to comments made by Dr M.K. MCIntosh, then Deputy Secretary, Acquisition and Logistics, Department of Defence, to a Senate Estimates Committee on 10 October 1989 (Senate Estimates Committee Hansard, 10 October 1989, page 333) about the need for the Government to approve relocating the construction of modules for the ANZAC Ships Project. (2) Does the relocation of the construction of modules for the ANZAC Ships Project require Government approval. (3) Did he approve the relocation of the constructhe tion of a module by Tenix Defence Systems for frigates Nos. 6 to 10 from the Hunter region to New Zealand; if so, (a) when and (b) were members of parliament from the Hunter region advised; if so, in each case, when. (4) When is New Zealand required to decide if it will accept an option to extend its order for ANZAC ships. (5) Did he discuss the relocation referred to in part (3) with the New Zealand Minister for Defence; if so (a) when and (b) was it within the context of New Zealand ordering additional ships. (6) Has an agreement been reached between the Australian and New Zealand Governments for New Zealand to acquire additional ANZAC ships. (7) Was the relocation of module construction discussed with the Prime Minister of New Zealand during her visit in early 1998. (8) Has the New Zealand Prime Minister or Minister for Defence given assurances regarding the extension of New Zealand's order for ANZAC ships; if so, were they given in the context of increasing contract expenditure in New Zealand. Mr MCLachlan-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. (2) and (3) (a) and (b) There is no requirement for Government or Ministerial approval for changes to sub-contracting arrangements that are made within the terms of the ANZAC Ship Contract. However, the ANZAC Ship Contract requires the contractor to notify the Department of Defence of changes of sub-contractors and details of work being performed by sub-contractors, and this includes the relocation of the construction of modules for the ANZAC Ship Project. The Department cannot unreasonably withhold its approval of the change if there is a valid commercial reason for change and the proposed change does not breach the contracted balance of work between Australian and New Zealand industry. (4) There was a fully priced contract option for two additional ANZAC Ships for New Zealand which had to be exercised by November 1997. New Zealand did not exercise this option. There is also an unpriced contract option for an additional two ships for New Zealand which remains open for the term of the Contract. (5) No. (6) There is no agreement between the Australian and New Zealand Governments regarding the purchase of additional ANZAC Ships, other than the ANZAC Ship Contract and the Treaty between Australia and New Zealand relating to the purchase of ANZAC Ships. These agreements were entered into in 1989. (7) No. (8) The New Zealand Government has given no assurances that it will purchase additional ANZAC Ships. If additional ANZAC Ships are ordered by New Zealand within the context of both the ANZAC Ship Contract and Treaty, then the workshare would need to be consistent with the principles of these documents. New Zealand could enter into a separate commercial arrangement with Tenix Defence Systems for further ANZAC ships. Such an arrangement would be outside the terms of the extant Contract and Treaty and would therefore not be bound by the existing workshare arrangements.
